bestBHT.bht: Ministers and missionaries today are not bound by the literal sense of Jesus' command, but they should follow its spirit. They are to rely on others for support, going without extra provisions or clothing, and trusting that the workman is worthy of his sustenance. This applies to all involved in the Lord's work, reminding us that preaching the gospel should not be about making a living but answering a calling, free from worldly care.

Henry Alford: This is a common truth of life—men give one who works for them his food and more; here uttered however by our Lord in its highest sense, as applied to the workmen in His vineyard.

It is a gross perversion and foolish bondage to the letter, to imagine that ministers of congregations, or even missionaries among the heathen, at this day are bound by the literal sense of our Lord’s commands in this passage.

But we must not therefore imagine that they are not bound by the spirit of them. This literal first mission was but a foreshadowing of the spiritual subsequent sending out of the ministry over the world, which ought therefore in spirit everywhere to be conformed to these rules.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Take no change of dress, no additional articles.
They were not to procure even that much expressly for this missionary journey, but to go with what they had.
The workman is worthy of his meat; a principle which, being universally recognized in secular affairs, is here authoritatively applied to the services of the Lord's workmen.
Marvin Vincent: But when the apostle departeth, let him take nothing except bread enough till he lodge again, but is he ask money, he is a false prophet.
Likewise a true teacher, he also is worthy like the workman, of his support.
John Calvin: They have no reason to dread that they will suffer hunger; because, wherever they come, they will at least be worthy of their food.
He calls them laborers, not that they resembled ordinary ministers... but merely because they were the heralds of a richer and more complete doctrine.
They did not at that time receive the office of preaching any farther than to render the Jews attentive to the preaching of the Gospel.
Philip Schaff: They were to be free from care, not seeking any profit from their office; outwardly unburdened, inwardly carrying the greatest treasures.
Without money or luggage they would be most free from care, for the workman is worthy of his meat (or ‘sustenance.’)

Matthew 10:8, in forbidding the spirit of covetousness in the ministry, shows that the preaching of the gospel should not become a mere livelihood; this verse shows that the laborers should be without worldly care.
Archibald T. Robertson: No wallet (μη πηραν). Better than 'scrip.' It can be either a travelling or bread bag.
For the labourer is worthy of his food (αξιος γαρ ο εργατης της τροφης αυτου). The sermon is worth the dinner, in other words.
The well-known Didach or Teaching of the Twelve (xiii) shows that in the second century there was still a felt need for care on the subject of receiving pay for preaching.
John Gill: The disciples were neither to carry money with them, nor any provisions for their journey.
They were not allowed change of raiment; either because superfluous, or too magnificent to appear in, or too troublesome to carry.
What sort these [sandals] were, the disciples were allowed to travel with, is not certain.
John Wesley: Neither scrip — That is, a wallet, or bag to hold provisions: Nor yet a staff - We read, Mark 6:8, Take nothing, save a staff only. He that had one might take it; they that had none, might not provide any.

For the workman is worthy of his maintenance — The word includes all that is mentioned in the9th and10th verses; Matthew 10:9,10 all that they were forbidden to provide for themselves, so far as it was needful for them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Ministers and missionaries today are not bound by the literal sense of Jesus' command in Matthew 10:10, but they are still called to follow the spirit of it. They are to rely on the support of others, going without extra provisions or clothing, and trusting that the workman is worthy of his sustenance. This principle applies to all who are involved in the Lord's work, including teachers, who are also deserving of support. It is a reminder that the preaching of the gospel should not become merely a means of livelihood, but a calling to be free from worldly care.

Ministers and missionaries today are not bound by the literal sense of Jesus' command in this passage, but they should still follow its spirit. They are to rely on others for support, going without extra provisions or clothing, and trusting that the workman is worthy of his sustenance. This principle applies to all involved in the Lord's work, including teachers. It reminds us that preaching the gospel should not be about making a living but answering a calling, free from worldly care.

Ministers and missionaries today are not bound by the literal sense of Jesus' command, but they should follow its spirit. They are to rely on others for support, going without extra provisions or clothing, and trusting that the workman is worthy of his sustenance. This applies to all involved in the Lord's work, reminding us that preaching the gospel should not be about making a living but answering a calling, free from worldly care.

Jesus' command to his disciples in Matthew 10:10 reminds us that ministers and missionaries are not bound by the literal sense of the instruction, yet they are still obligated to follow its spirit. They are to rely on the support of others, without carrying extra provisions, clothing, or money, demonstrating their trust and faith in being worthy of their sustenance. This principle extends beyond the disciples to all who are involved in the Lord's work, emphasizing the importance of focusing on the calling rather than seeking worldly gain.

The workman in the Lord's vineyard is worthy of his support, as emphasized in these commentaries. While ministers and missionaries today are not bound by the literal sense of Jesus' command, they are still called to follow its spirit. This means relying on the provision of others and going without extra provisions or clothing. It serves as a reminder that the preaching of the gospel should not be driven by monetary gain, but rather by a God-given calling that transcends worldly concerns.
